PROJECTS

Functional Data Analysis (Functional Registration)

Functional data — curves, shapes, and other complex structures — arise in fields like biology, medicine, and the social sciences. My primary research focuses on functional registration using the Fisher-Rao metric within a Riemannian manifold framework.

Functional registration addresses phase variation (temporal misalignment) to align functions in a geometrically meaningful way.

Consider a smooth function, $f(t)$. The left plot shows the warping function $\gamma(t)$, and the right plot shows the aligned function $f(\gamma(t))$.

Correcting phase variation enables more accurate statistical analysis. To address computational challenges, we utilize the Square Root Velocity Function (SRVF) representation (Srivastava et al., 2011).

▫ Peak Persistence Diagrams (PPD)

In practice, functional data often contains noise and small fluctuations. When applying dynamic time warping (DTW) with the Fisher-Rao metric, this noise can lead to over-alignment (warping functions matching insignificant noise).

To mitigate this, we propose the Peak Persistence Diagram (PPD). PPD helps identify and summarize significant internal peaks, offering robustness to noise while remaining sensitive to meaningful structural patterns, avoiding the need for arbitrary penalty term selection.

▫ Bayesian Functional Alignment (on-going)

We are developing a Bayesian framework for functional registration to handle noisy and misaligned data more robustly than classical optimization methods.

Unlike DTW, which finds a single global optimum, the Bayesian approach models the full posterior distribution of warping functions. This allows us to incorporate prior information and capture multiple plausible warping solutions (multimodality).

We have successfully developed a method for simultaneous registration and signal estimation. A short report is available.

Network Analysis via Bayesian Method

(Hierarchical Latent SVD Model)

In social network analysis, Latent Space Models (LDMs) embed nodes in a latent space to uncover structure. Hoff (2008) introduced eigenmodel-based LDMs to account for homophily (the tendency of similar nodes to connect).

"Homophily helps explain common patterns in social networks, including transitivity and the formation of cohesive subgroups." (Hoff 2008)

This project applies Bayesian hierarchical modeling to latent SVD models to induce shrinkage effects and improve parameter estimation by borrowing strength across the network structure.

Topological Feature Extraction

With Human Brain Connectome

We explored how Topological Data Analysis (TDA) can reveal structural patterns in brain connectivity. Using multi-level white matter tractography datasets, we applied persistent homology to capture features like loops and voids across scales.
